ActionParameters.HTML:
Correct



Begin by pulling at the gown midsection to break the waist ties, then, using both hands, grab the gown in the front of your chest crossing arms and slowly extend your arms fully in front of you pulling the gown off and forward. The goal is to roll the gown up slowly turning the contaminated outer surface internally. You should lean slightly forward and hold it fully away.
ActionParameters.Title: Remove gown & gloves together
Leave the room to remove PPE
Doff gloves and place in garbage
Put on gloves

Correct



Put on gloves ensuring gown cuffs are covered

ActionParameters.Title: Enter the patient room
ActionParameters.HTML:
Correct

Perform final PPE inspection BEFORE entering the patient care area and THEN enter the patient room.

BEFORE DONNING: Please be familiar with your local operational arrangements and procedures regarding PPE. The following video is for hospital healthcare workers involved in the assessment and care of individuals with possible or confirmed COVID-19. This video covers how to put on (don) PPE correctly and remove (doff) PPE correctly and safely.


REMINDER: PPE is one part of a Safe System of Working. Only clinical staff that are trained and competent in the use of PPE, should be allowed to enter a patient's room or clinical setting.


WARNING: The CDC recommends the use of a trained observer, or buddy, to assist with the safe donning and doffing of PPE. When a trained observer is not available, please follow instructions on your institutional donning/doffing checklists and ensure each step is completed correctly. This video will not have a trained observer.

John Jones is a previously healthy 65-year-old Caucasian male who was admitted for observation for acute respiratory symptoms. 


He has a dry cough, mild fever, and difficulty breathing. Mr. Jones flu test was negative and results from a COVID-19 lab test are still pending.


Mr. Jones is resting comfortably as you prepare to visit his patient room on morning rounds.


Now it is your turn to practice donning PPE. Click the highlighted objects within the eMicroSim environment and then select from the list of pop-up items to make decisions.

The CDC recommends the use of a trained observer, or buddy, to assist with the safe donning and doffing of PPE. When a trained observer is not available, please follow instructions on your institutional donning/doffing checklists and ensure each step is completed correctly. It is recommended one use the restroom and hydrate prior to donning PPE.

1.HTML:
Instructions


During this eMicroSim you will complete the following steps:


1. Watch short videos on Donning and Doffing PPE.

2. After each video, perform steps within the eMicroSim.

3. Take a short quiz.

4. Review references and a debriefing report.

5. Review your score on the leaderboard.


Note: In this eMicroSim, you will only be selecting the healthcare provider.



Good luck and thank you for taking this brief learning exercise.

ActionParameters.HTML:
You are now in the patient room, so remember:


  • If gloves are grossly contaminated, use purple wipes & allow to dry for 2 minutes. 
  • Do not turn your back to the patient (to keep back of gown clean). 
  • Avoid readjusting PPE (especially face shield/goggles) while in the room 
  • Limit touching surfaces in the patient care area to reduce risk of contamination

You have completed your work with the patient and are ready to start the doffing process. Begin the doffing process inside the room at least six feet from the patient in an area that is safe to do so. Preferably by the door.

ActionParameters.HTML: You are outside the room and prepared to continue the doffing process.

1.HTML: Effective hand hygiene is a critical component of proper donning and doffing of PPE.

2.HTML: The following items are important elements of PPE: Gown, Gloves, Eye Protection, N 95 Respirator Mask.

3.HTML: When putting on the N 95 Mask, be sure to crimp the nose piece and perform a fit and leak test.

4.HTML: Goggles or a Face Shield are OK to use, but not very important parts of this PPE protocol.

5.HTML: Exam Gloves should be worn, making sure to extend them securely over the wrists (sleeve cuffs) of the gown.

6.HTML: Properly removing, or doffing your PPE is a good idea, but not nearly as important as proper donning.

7.HTML: A properly donned gown should cover the torso completely and be securely fastened.

8.HTML: Do not enter the patient’s room until you have properly donned and checked all of the necessary PPE required to meet protocol for treating a patient suspected of being infected with COVID 19.

9.HTML: Proper hand hygiene protocol is just as important to follow when removing or doffing PPE, as when donning PPE.

10.HTML: PPE is to be removed at the appropriate disposal site in the patient’s care area, prior to exiting the patient’s care area.

11.HTML: It is recommended you hydrate and use the restroom prior to donning PPE.

competent.Text:
COMPETENT

It is often difficult to apply content knowledge to real-life scenarios. To build confidence, it is important to understand how experts think and act through these scenarios.

To help build confidence, the micro-simulation case will offer two types of remediation.

First: An “Expert Review” button enables the understanding of how our expert integrates his/her knowledge base and thought process to solve this micro-simulation case. The learner is encouraged to pause throughout the expert’s explanation in order to critically absorb the information, evaluate the actions the learner would have taken with this information, and to fully understand the reasons the expert took the approach he/she did.

Second: An “Enhance Knowledge” button offers pertinent information to enhance the learner’s knowledge base about the fundamentals required for these types of patient scenarios. The learner is encouraged to pause throughout this section to thoroughly review the information until he/she fully understands and can explain the concepts.
competent.Review:
COMPETENT REVIEW

It is often difficult to apply content knowledge to real-life scenarios. To build confidence, it is important to understand how experts think and act through these scenarios.

To help build your confidence, please follow the following recommendations below:

First: Select the “Expert Review” button to help you understand how our expert integrates his/her knowledge base and thought process to solve this micro-simulation case. You are encouraged to pause throughout the expert’s explanation in order to critically absorb the information, evaluate the actions you would have taken with this information, and to fully understand the reasons the expert took the approach he/she did.

Second (Optional): Select the “Enhance Knowledge” button to improve your knowledge base about the fundamentals required for these types of patient scenarios. You are encouraged to pause throughout this section to thoroughly review the information until you fully understand and can explain the concepts.
competent.Hover: Improve confidence to apply knowledge to real-life scenarios or cases

cognitivebias.Review:
COGNITIVE BIAS REVIEW

Your confidence level has exceeded your current abilities. This overconfidence phenomenon is called cognitive bias. Cognitive bias exists in learners as they integrate their learned knowledge with real-life scenarios.

To help you reduce your cognitive bias and narrow the gap between your knowledge and confidence, please follow the recommendations below:

First: Select the “Expert Review” button to help you understand how our expert integrates his/her knowledge base and thought process to solve this micro-simulation case.

Second: Select the “Enhance Knowledge” button to improve your knowledge base about the fundamentals required for these types of patient scenarios.
cognitivebias.Hover: When confidence levels exceed current abilities
cognitivebias.Text:
COGNITIVE BIAS

This is when confidence levels exceed current abilities. This overconfidence phenomenon is called cognitive bias. Cognitive bias is very common in learners as they integrate their learned knowledge with real-life scenarios.

To help you reduce your cognitive bias and narrow the gap between your knowledge and confidence, please follow the recommendations as prescribed below:

First: An “Expert Review” button enables the understanding of how our expert integrates his/her knowledge base and thought process to solve this micro-simulation case.

Second: An “Enhance Knowledge” button offers pertinent information to enhance the learner’s knowledge base about the fundamentals required for these types of patient scenarios.

unprepared.Text:
UNPREPARED

It requires a high level of content mastery to apply knowledge to real-life scenarios. It is critical to transition from memorizing content to understanding content. As learners make this transition, confidence will rise as well.

To help increase content understanding, the micro-simulation case will offer two types of remediation.

First: An “Enhance Knowledge” button offers pertinent information to enhance the learner’s knowledge base about the fundamentals required for these types of patient scenarios. The learner is encouraged to pause throughout this section to thoroughly review the information until he/she fully understands and can explain the concepts before moving on to the next section.

Second: An “Expert Review” button enables the understanding of how our expert integrates his/her knowledge base and thought process to solve this micro-simulation case. The learner is encouraged to pause throughout the expert’s explanation in order to critically absorb the information, evaluate the actions the learner would have taken with this information, and to fully understand the reasons the expert took the approach he/she did.
unprepared.Review:
UNPREPARED REVIEW

It requires a high level of content mastery to apply knowledge to real-life scenarios. It is important to transition from memorizing content to understanding content. As learners make this transition, confidence will rise.

To help increase content understanding, please follow the recommendations below:

First: Select the “Enhance Knowledge” button to improve your knowledge base about the fundamentals required for these types of patient scenarios. You are encouraged to pause throughout this section to thoroughly review the information until you fully understand and can explain the concepts before moving on to the next section.

Second: Select the “Expert Review” button to help you understand how our expert integrates his/her knowledge base and thought process to solve this micro-simulation case. You are encouraged to pause throughout the expert’s explanation in order to critically absorb the information, evaluate the actions you would have taken with this information, and to fully understand the reasons the expert took the approach he/she did.
unprepared.Hover: Improve knowledge to confidently apply knowledge to real-life scenarios or cases

confident.Review:
CONFIDENT REVIEW

Great work! Please move on to the next micro-simulation. If you are interested, please feel free to select the “Expert Review” and “Enhance Knowledge” buttons for additional notes and knowledge about the case.
confident.Text:
CONFIDENT

Great work! Please move on to the next micro-simulation. If you are interested, please feel free to select the “Expert Review” button below for notes on the case.
confident.Hover: High Knowledge and Confidence applied to real-life scenarios or cases

pages.name: Introduction
pages.html:
The following learning experience is intended for hospital healthcare workers involved in the assessment and care of individuals with suspected or confirmed COVID-19. This guidance is specific to COVID-19 and based on current CDC guidelines and Infection Prevention best practices. Your organization may have additional recommendations or protocols beyond that which is required by the CDC.


As you move through this interactive module, please keep in mind: 

  • Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is just one control in protecting workers from workplace hazards.
  • Only clinical staff who are trained and competent in the use of this PPE should be allowed to enter the patient’s room.
  • Healthcare workers must be familiar with local and institutional operational guidelines for the safe care of patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19.
  • Hospitals need to identify areas to safely don and doff PPE.
  • When possible, the donning and doffing process should be supervised by a trained observer. A Trained Observer is a member of the staff who is also trained and competent in the use of the PPE whose sole responsibility is to guide health care providers as they don (put on) and doff (take off) personal protective equipment, or PPE.

pages.name: Sponsors
pages.html: This learning experience was made free for use by the following organizations: SimUAB®, EVMS and eTrainetc.

Warning

eTrainetc, LLC and their Partners and Sponsors do Not Engage in Practice of Medicine. eTrainetc, LLC does not, nor does it intend to, engage in the performance or delivery of medical or hospital services or other types of healthcare. eTrainetc’s offerings under this module should not, in any case, be deemed or understood as a recommendation, endorsement, guarantee or warranty of the professional services of Learners or any providers who render healthcare services. Nothing herein shall be construed to imply that eTrainetc, or any of eTrainetc’s subsidiaries, officers, directors, employees, partners or agents are engaged in the practice of medicine or other professions related thereto. All matters related to such field shall be the exclusive province of you the customer (organization using this module) and its staff, agents and employees.
pages.name: Warning

pages.html:
This module is intended to help healthcare providers reduce the risk for SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19) transmission. The information here is drawn primarily from U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) recommendations. Please note that guidance may vary based on your organization and continued updated guidelines. Outside of the U.S., consult the World Health Organization (WHO) and local health resources.


Infection Control: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). (2020, March 19). Retrieved March 25, 2020, from https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/infection-control/control-recommendations.html


Krein, S. L., Mayer, J., Harrod, M., Weston, L. E., Gregory, L., Petersen, L., … Drews, F. A. (2018). Identification and Characterization of Failures in Infectious Agent Transmission Precaution Practices in Hospitals. JAMA Internal Medicine, 178(8), 1016. doi: 10.1001/jamainternmed.2018.1898 Retrieved March 20, 2020, from https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/2683488


PPE-Sequence.pdf. (n.d.). Retrieved March 20, 2020, from https://www.cdc.gov/hai/pdfs/ppe/PPE-Sequence.pdf


US Department of Labor. (n.d.). Home [YouTube Channel]. Retrieved March 25, 2020 from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tzpz5fko-fg


US Department of Labor. (n.d.) Recommended Practices for Safety and Health Programs. Retrieved July 23, 2020 from https://www.osha.gov/shpguidelines/hazard-prevention.html


Observer: Introduction (2019, July 25). Retrieved July 23, 2020 from https://www.cdc.gov/vhf/ebola/hcp/ppe-training/trained-observer/observer_01.html


What Healthcare Personnel Should Know about Caring for Patients with Confirmed or Possible COVID-19 Infection. (2020, March 10). Retrieved March 20, 2020, from https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/caring-for-patients.html
pages.name: References

pages.html:
Micro-Simulation on the CDC recommended guidelines for Donning and Doffing of PPE.  


This is a 10-minute module that offers a video review of the proper procedure for donning and doffing personal protective equipment (PPE) followed by a micro-simulation case for the medical professional to don and doff PPE in a virtual environment. eTrainetc, LLC’s (eTrain) unique module tests knowledge and confidence and provides necessary recommendations for improvement to the learner. This module is based on best practices. 


MicroSim Learning Objectives:

  • Understand the basis for PPE use
  • Demonstrate proper donning and doffing sequence for COVID-19 respiratory enhanced PPE
  • Use the knowledge gained in the eMicroSim to safely assess and care of individuals with suspected or confirmed COVID-19
pages.name: Learning Objectives

sim.title: Introduction
sim.content:
The following learning experience is intended for hospital healthcare workers involved in the assessment and care of individuals with suspected or confirmed COVID-19. This guidance is specific to COVID-19 and based on current CDC guidelines and Infection Prevention best practices. Your organization may have additional recommendations or protocols beyond that which is required by the CDC. 
 As you move through this interactive module, please keep in mind: 
 Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is just one control in protecting workers from workplace hazards. 
 Only clinical staff who are trained and competent in the use of this PPE should be allowed to enter the patients room. 
 Healthcare workers must be familiar with local and institutional operational guidelines for the safe care of patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19. 
 Hospitals need to identify areas to safely don and doff PPE. 
 When possible, the donning and doffing process should be supervised by a trained observer. A Trained Observer is a member of the staff who is also trained and competent in the use of the PPE whose sole responsibility is to guide health care providers as they don (put on) and doff (take off) personal protective equipment, or PPE.

 eTrainetcs offerings under this module should not, in any case, be deemed or understood as a recommendation, endorsement, guarantee or warranty of the professional services of Learners or any providers who render healthcare services. Nothing herein shall be construed to imply that eTrainetc, or any of eTrainetcs subsidiaries, officers, directors, employees, partners or agents are engaged in the practice of medicine or other professions related thereto. All matters related to such field shall be the exclusive province of you the customer (organization using this module) and its staff, agents and employees.

sim.title: Learning Objectives
sim.content:
Micro-Simulation on the CDC recommended guidelines for Donning and Doffing of PPE. 
 This is a 10-minute module that offers a video review of the proper procedure for donning and doffing personal protective equipment (PPE) followed by a micro-simulation case for the medical professional to don and doff PPE in a virtual environment. eTrainetc, LLCs (eTrain) unique module tests knowledge and confidence and provides necessary recommendations for improvement to the learner. This module is based on best practices. 
 MicroSim Learning Objectives: 
 - Understand the basis for PPE use 
 - Demonstrate proper donning and doffing sequence for COVID-19 respiratory enhanced PPE 
 - Use the knowledge gained in the eMicroSim to safely assess and care of individuals with suspected or confirmed COVID-19

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Instructions. 
 During this eMicroSim you will complete the following steps:
 1. Watch short videos on Donning and Doffing PPE.
 2. After each video, perform steps within the eMicroSim.
 3. Take short quiz.
 4. Review references and a debriefing report.
 5. Review your score on the leaderboard.
 Note: In this eMicroSim, you only be selecting the healthcare provider.
 Good luck and thank you for taking this brief learning exercise.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
BEFORE DONNING: Please be familiar with your local operational arrangements and procedures regarding PPE. The following video is for hospital healthcare workers involved in the assessment and care of individuals with possible or confirmed COVID-19. This video covers how to put on (don) PPE correctly and remove (doff) PPE correctly and safely.

 REMINDER: PPE is one part of a Safe System of Working. Only clinical staff that are trained and competent in the use of PPE, should be allowed to enter a patient's room or clinical setting.

 WARNING: The CDC recommends the use of a trained observer, or buddy, to assist with the safe donning and doffing of PPE. When a trained observer is not available, please follow instructions on your institutional donning/doffing checklists and ensure

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
John Jones is a previously healthy 65-year-old Caucasian male who was admitted for observation for acute respiratory symptoms. 

 He has a dry cough, mild fever, and difficulty breathig. Mr. Jones flu test was negative and results from a COVID-19 lab test are still pending. 

 Mr. Jones is resting comfortably as you prepare to visit his patient room on morning rounds. 

 Now it is your turn to practice donning PPE. Click the highlighted objects within the eMicroSim environment and then select from the list of pop-up items to make decisions. 
 Good luck and thank you for taking this brief learning exercise.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
The CDC recommends the use of the trained observer, or buddy, to assist with the safe donning and doffing of PPE.
 When a trained observer is not available, please follow instructions on your institutional donning/doffing checklists and ensure each step is completed correctly.
 It is recommended one use the restroom and hydrate prior to donning PPE.

sim.title: Info
sim.content: Begin preparation for donning PPE

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText2: Put on gloves and enter Mr.Jones patient room
sim.btnText3: Remove anything that might puncture PPE
sim.btnText4: Continue to other patients on rounds until Mr. Jones COVID-19 test results are available

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct.
Jewelry, pens, badges, etc. can puncture PPE and should be removed.

sim.title: Info
sim.content: Begin the donning process outside of the patient room.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText2: Put on gloves and enter Mr.Jones patient room

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Gather PPE for COVID-19 Enhanced Respiratory Precautuins (N95 mask, isolation gown, gloves, face shield).

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText2: Inspect all exposed skin for wounds

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct.
Inspect all exposed skin for wounds, cuts, and scrapes.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Use hand sanitizer and allow to dry fully (20 seconds) OR wash with soap and water.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct.
Put on isolation gown.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Put on N95 mask and perform a fit check.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct.
Put on face shield.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Put on gloves ensuring gown cuffs are covered

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct.
Perform final PPE inspection BEFORE entering the patient care area and THEN enter the patient room.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
You are in the patient room, so remember: 

 - If gloves are grossly contaminated, use purple wipes & allow to dry for 2 minutes. 

 - Do not turn back to the patient (to keep back of gown clean). 

 - Avoid readjusting PPE (especially face shield/goggles) while in the room. 

 - Limit touching surfaces in the patient care area to reduce risk of contamination.

sim.title: Info
sim.content: You have completed your work with the patient and are ready to start the doffing process. Begin the doffing process inside the room at least six feet from the patient in an area that is safe to do so. Preferably by the door.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText1: Doff gown and place in garbage
sim.btnText2: Perform hand hygiene with ETOH-based hand sanitizer
sim.btnText3: Doff gloves and place in garbage

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Perform hand hygiene with ETOH-based hand sanitizer. Use purple wipes IF you note any gross cantamination and allow to dry for 2 minutes.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText3: Doff gloves and place in garbage
sim.btnText4: Leave the room to remove PPE

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Begin by pulling at the gown midsection to break the waist ties, then, using both hands, grab the gown in the front of your chest crossing arms and slowly extend your arms fully in front of you pulling the gown off and forward. The goal is to roll the gown up slowly turning the contaminated outer surface internally. You should lean slightly forward and hold it fully away.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText1: Set gown and gloves on the floor by the door
sim.btnText2: Drop gown and gloves in garbage

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Drop gown and gloves in garbage.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText3: Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Perform hand hygiene with ETOH-based hand sanitizer.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText2: Doff gloves and place in garbage

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Disinfect front of face shield with purple wipe (while still on HCW face) being careful not to touch the inside og the shield.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText2: Doff gloves and place in garbage

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Doff gloves and place in garbage.

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Perform hand hygiene with ETOH-based hand sanitizer.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText4: Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Leave the room and prepare to continue the doffing process.

sim.title: Info
sim.content: You are outside the room and prepared to continue the doffing process

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText1: Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Perform hand hygiene with ETOH-based hand sanitizer.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText2: Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Remove face shield - reach back, grab the strap and pull it over towards the front. Place on bedside table or designated surface for re-use.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText4: Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Perform hand hygiene with ETOH-based hand sanitizer.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText1: Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Remove N95 mask, making sure to only touch straps of mask, and drop in garbage.

sim.title: Healthcare provider
sim.btnText2: Don new pair of clean gloves
sim.btnText4: Don new pair of clean gloves

sim.title: Info
sim.content:
Correct
Perform hand hygiene with ETOH-based hand sanitizer.

sim.title: info
sim.content: Congratulations, you have completed the VR PPE Demo. Click OK to restart.
